posts.post_content:
Combo Machine!  
  
This + [Mystic Snake](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mystic Snake), [Draining Whelk](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Draining Whelk), or [Venser, Shaper Savant](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Venser, Shaper Savant)= reusable [Counterspell](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Counterspell)/[Boomerang](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Boomerang) for 1U.  
  
This guy can also blink himself to dodge removal,  
or even to Soulbond with a different creature and blink \*them\* afterwards-  
basically, this guy enables shenanigans galore in any format with plentiful mana.  
  
And not to link to it again,   
but [Training Grounds](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Training Grounds) will allow you to go even *more* blink-crazy with this guy.
posts.html:
Combo Machine!

This + Mystic Snake, Draining Whelk, or Venser, Shaper Savant= reusable Counterspell/Boomerang for 1U.

This guy can also blink himself to dodge removal,
or even to Soulbond with a different creature and blink *them* afterwards-
basically, this guy enables shenanigans galore in any format with plentiful mana.

And not to link to it again,
but Training Grounds will allow you to go even more blink-crazy with this guy.

posts.post_content:
Yanked a foil version during prerelease and had a ton of fun with [Voice of the Provinces](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Voice of the Provinces) and [Mist Raven](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mist Raven). If I didn't already finish off an opponent with the [Craterhoof Behemoth](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Craterhoof Behemoth) and a full board, I woulda abused the ETB on him too.  
  
With the number of creatures with ETB effects, and not just in this set, the potential for abuse is huge. Get your [Torpor Orb](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Torpor Orb)s now, while they're cheap.  
  
If it weren't rare and 6CMC, it's be busted as hell.

posts.post_content:
My only real issue with this card is the wording for the flicker ability. Right now it says '*then return it to the battlefield under* **your** *control*', when it should really say '*then return it to the battlefield under* **its owner's** *control*'.  
  
The number of games I've had someone steal my creature with a spell, bond it with this guy, and then go to town with my abilities...  
  
There are only 3 other multi-use instances of this wording on a permanent, and all of those are conditional ([Conjurer's Closet](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Conjurer's Closet) triggers at EOT, [Nephalia Smuggler](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Nephalia Smuggler) costs 4 mana and taps, and [Venser, the Sojourner](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Venser, the Sojourner) can only be used at sorcery speed and only once a turn).
posts.html:
My only real issue with this card is the wording for the flicker ability. Right now it says 'then return it to the battlefield under your control', when it should really say 'then return it to the battlefield under its owner's control'.

The number of games I've had someone steal my creature with a spell, bond it with this guy, and then go to town with my abilities...

There are only 3 other multi-use instances of this wording on a permanent, and all of those are conditional (Conjurer's Closet triggers at EOT, Nephalia Smuggler costs 4 mana and taps, and Venser, the Sojourner can only be used at sorcery speed and only once a turn).

posts.post_content:
One of two cards in all of existence that I absolutely refuse to play in EDH, along with Jace, the Mind Sculptor. When Sylvan Primordial was banned, I immediately said that they should've cut to the chase and ban the instigator, this piece of crap.  
  
And I'm the guy who runs Erayo, Soratami Ascendant and Ethersworn Canonist to lock down a game. I've never pulled it off, but I have been the victim of Deadeye on more than eight occasions, all in different decks not run by the same player. It's cheap, durdle crap. Should be banned.

In Theros, he goes nicely with black. I like to pair him up with [Gray Merchant of Asphodel](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Gray Merchant of Asphodel), [Disciple of Phenax](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Disciple of Phenax), and [Abhorrent Overlord](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Abhorrent Overlord).  
But the true love of this card is [Master of Waves](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Master of Waves). In-color, and because state-based actions aren't checked while the ability resolves, his tokens don't die when you flicker him.

posts.post_content:
Rules lawyer here, reminding you that state based actions are not check during resolution, therefor the combo list of this guy now includes [Master of Waves](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Master of Waves)... And this guy provides two devotion as well.  
  
I suppose I should paste the actual rule here because, this combo just got called shenanigans.  
  
704.4. Unlike triggered abilities, state-based actions pay no attention to what happens during the resolution of a spell or ability.  
  
Example: A player controls a creature with the ability "This creature’s power and toughness are each equal to the number of cards in your hand” and casts a spell whose effect is "Discard your hand, then draw seven cards." The creature will temporarily have toughness 0 in the middle of the spell’s resolution but will be back up to toughness 7 when the spell finishes resolving. Thus the creature will survive when state-based actions are checked. In contrast, an ability that triggers when the player has no cards in hand goes on the stack aft... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
Rules lawyer here, reminding you that state based actions are not check during resolution, therefor the combo list of this guy now includes Master of Waves... And this guy provides two devotion as well.

I suppose I should paste the actual rule here because, this combo just got called shenanigans.

704.4. Unlike triggered abilities, state-based actions pay no attention to what happens during the resolution of a spell or ability.

Example: A player controls a creature with the ability "This creature’s power and toughness are each equal to the number of cards in your hand” and casts a spell whose effect is "Discard your hand, then draw seven cards." The creature will temporarily have toughness 0 in the middle of the spell’s resolution but will be back up to toughness 7 when the spell finishes resolving. Thus the creature will survive when state-based actions are checked. In contrast, an ability that triggers when the player has no cards in hand goes on the stack aft... (see all)

posts.post_content:
Has anybody mentioned that [Deadeye Navigator](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Deadeye Navigator) makes a great reanimation engine with [Dreams of the Dead](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Dreams of the Dead), [Whip of Erebos](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Whip of Erebos), and/or [Corpse Dance](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Corpse Dance)? The latter two can also be used to reanimate the Navigator itself!  
  
[Dreams of the Dead](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Dreams of the Dead) gives you: ![2](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=2&type=symbol)![Blue](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=U&type=symbol)![Blue](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=U&type=symbol): Return target white or black creature from your graveyard to the battlefield. Then exile it and return it to the battlefield.  
[Whip of Erebos](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Whip of Erebos) gives you: ![3](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=3&type=symbol)![Blue](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=U&type=symbol)![Black](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=B&type=symbol)![Black](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=B&type=symbol): Return target creature from your graveyard to the battlefield. It gains haste until end of turn. Activate this ability only during your turn and only once per turn.  
[Corpse Dance](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Corpse Dance) gives you: ![5](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=5&type=symbol)![Blue](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=U&type=symbol)![Black](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=B&type=symbol): Put the top creature card in your graveyard onto the battlefield. It gains haste until end of turn.
posts.html:
Has anybody mentioned that Deadeye Navigator makes a great reanimation engine with Dreams of the Dead, Whip of Erebos, and/or Corpse Dance? The latter two can also be used to reanimate the Navigator itself!

Dreams of the Dead gives you: : Return target white or black creature from your graveyard to the battlefield. Then exile it and return it to the battlefield.
Whip of Erebos gives you: : Return target creature from your graveyard to the battlefield. It gains haste until end of turn. Activate this ability only during your turn and only once per turn.
Corpse Dance gives you: : Put the top creature card in your graveyard onto the battlefield. It gains haste until end of turn.
